title: Localize the Service Catalog
content:
If your Service Portal users use one or more languages other than English, you can localize the Service Catalog (including categories, offerings, and service definitions) into one or more of the languages supported by Service Management.  
If the catalog records are localized into a user's language, Service Portal displays categories, offerings, and service definitions and search results in the user's language. For example, if the Service Catalog has been translated into French and Chinese, Service Portal users on the French and Chinese locales see the catalog records and search results in French and Chinese, respectively. 
Note If the catalog records aren't translated into the user's language or if an entry isn't translated, Service Portal displays the non-translated values to the user.

Service Catalog localization process

The Service Catalog localization process is as follows:
  1. Export your Service Catalog to a CSV file for each target language, which must be a language supported by Service Management.
    Note If you export a file with rich text fields to CSV and save it in Excel, the formatting may become corrupted, and the re-imported file may be displayed incorrectly.
  2. Translate the exported CSV files.
  3. Import the CSV files back into Service Management.
  4. Verify the localization in Service Portal.

Export the Service Catalog for localization

Export categories, offerings, and service definitions to CSV files for your target languages:

  1. From the main menu, select Plan > Service Catalog.
  2. Click the Categories, Offerings, or Service Definitions submenu.
  3. From the toolbar, click the More button, and select Export for localization.
  4. Select the languages for localization, and click Export. 

The following table lists the exported files for categories, offerings, and service definitions. Each ZIP file contains a corresponding CSV file for each language selected.

Number of languages selected Exported files Example
1
  • Categories_<language>.csv
  • Offerings_<language>.csv
  • ServiceDefinitions_<language>.csv

For French:

  • Categories_fr.csv
  • Offerings_fr.csv
  • ServiceDefinitions_fr.csv

For Chinese:

  • Categories_zh-CN.csv
  • Offerings_zh-CN.csv
  • ServiceDefinitions_zh-CN.csv
2 or more
  • Categories.zip
  • Offerings.zip
  • ServiceDefinitions.zip

If both French and Chinese are selected:

  • Categories.zip
    Contains Categories_fr.csv and Categories_zh-CN.csv.
  • Offerings.zip
    Contains Offerings_fr.csv and Offerings_zh-CN.csv.
  • ServiceDefinitions.zip
    Contains     ServiceDefinitions_fr.csv and ServiceDefinitions_zh-CN.csv.

Translate the exported CSV files

The OpenL10n community site offers the machine translation capability that allows you to automatically localize the Service Catalog data. For more information about how to use the OpenL10n tool, see Localize Service Catalog with OpenL10n.

To manually translate the Service Catalog data, follow these steps:

  • If the exported file is one CSV file, directly translate it:

    1. Open the CSV file in a text editor such as Notepad.

    2. For each record, translate the values in the Source Value fields, and enter their translations into the Translated Value fields.

      Note Do not delete the quotation marks.

    3. Save your changes.

  • If the exported file is a ZIP file, do the following:
    1. Unzip the file. 
    2. Translate each CSV file in the ZIP file. 
    3. (Recommended) Compress the translated CSV files back to a ZIP file. For example, compress all translated Offerings_*.csv files to TranslatedOfferings.zip, all Categories_*.csv files to TranslatedCategories.zip, and all ServiceDefinitions_*.csv files to TranslatedServiceDefinitions.zip. If you don't compress the translated CSV files to a ZIP file, you'll have to import them one by one. 

Import the translated CSV files

From Studio, import the translated CSV files for each record type (Category, Offering, and Service Definition). You must be an administrator to import translated files:

  1. From the main menu, select Administration > Configuration > Studio.
  2. In the drop-down list at the top of the page, select the relevant catalog area record type: Category, Service Definition, or Offering.
  3. In the Import translations tab, browse to the translated CSV or ZIP file (for example, Offerings_fr.csv or TranslatedOfferings.zip) for the record type that you are importing, and click Open.

  4. Click Import. A dialog box displays the progress of the import. At the end of the operation, the dialog box displays the results, including the number of records successfully imported and the number of failed records. Click the Details link to download a report of the failed records. The report displays the error for each failed record in the operation.

Verify the localization in Service Portal

  1. Log in to Service Portal as a user with a localization language.
  2. Verify that categries are displayed in that language.
  3. Search for an offering, and verify that the offering is displayed in that language.
Note: After you localize and import the catalog records according to above steps, when you use business rules or DSLs to retrieve the display label or description of a catalog record (such as ${entity.RequestsOffering.DisplayLabel}), only the source value will be returned, which won't be further localized.

Related topics

  • Service Catalog Management
